natural problem: Ten chairs are arranged in a circle. Find the number of subsets of this set of chairs that contain at least three adjacent chairs.
natural solution: We know that a subset with less than $3$ chairs cannot contain $3$ adjacent chairs. There are only $10$ sets of $3$ chairs so that they are all $3$ adjacent. There are $10$ subsets of $4$ chairs where all $4$ are adjacent, and $10 \cdot 5$ or $50$ where there are only $3.$ If there are $5$ chairs, $10$ have all $5$ adjacent, $10 \cdot 4$ or $40$ have $4$ adjacent, and $10 \cdot {5\choose 2}$ or $100$ have $3$ adjacent.

With $6$ chairs in the subset, $10$ have all $6$ adjacent, $10(3)$ or $30$ have $5$ adjacent, $10 \cdot {4\choose2}$ or $60$ have $4$ adjacent, $\frac{10 \cdot 3}{2}$ or $15$ have $2$ groups of $3$ adjacent chairs, and $10 \cdot \left({5\choose2} - 3\right)$ or $70$ have $1$ group of $3$ adjacent chairs.

All possible subsets with more than $6$ chairs have at least $1$ group of $3$ adjacent chairs, so we add ${10\choose7}$ or $120$, ${10\choose8}$ or $45$, ${10\choose9}$ or $10$, and ${10\choose10}$ or $1.$ Adding, we get $10 + 10 + 50 + 10 + 40 + 100 + 10 + 30 + 60 + 15 + 70 + 120 + 45 + 10 + 1 = \boxed{581}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum>k = 3..chairs. (chairs - k + 1))"
shows  "subsets = 581"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ten chairs are arranged in a circle. Find the number of subsets of this set of chairs that contain at least three adjacent chairs.
 The final Answer is 581
 ### Proof
 We know that a subset with less than $3$ chairs cannot contain $3$ adjacent chairs. There are only $10$ sets of $3$ chairs so that they are all $3$ adjacent. There are $10$ subsets of $4$ chairs where all $4$ are adjacent, and $10 \cdot 5$ or $50$ where there are only $3.$ If there are $5$ chairs, $10$ have all $5$ adjacent, $10 \cdot 4$ or $40$ have $4$ adjacent, and $10 \cdot {5\choose 2}$ or $100$ have $3$ adjacent.
 With $6$ chairs in the subset, $10$ have all $6$ adjacent, $10(3)$ or $30$ have $5$ adjacent, $10 \cdot {4\choose2}$ or $60$ have $4$ adjacent, $\frac{10 \cdot 3}{2}$ or $15$ have $2$ groups of $3$ adjacent chairs, and $10 \cdot \left({5\choose2} - 3\right)$ or $70$ have $1$ group of $3$ adjacent chairs.
 All possible subsets with more than $6$ chairs have at least $1$ group of $3$ adjacent chairs, so we add ${10\choose7}$ or $120$, ${10\choose8}$ or $45$, ${10\choose9}$ or $10$, and ${10\choose10}$ or $1.$ Adding, we get $10 + 10 + 50 + 10 + 40 + 100 + 10 + 30 + 60 + 15 + 70 + 120 + 45 + 10 + 1 = \boxed{581}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum>k = 3..chairs. (chairs - k + 1))"
shows  "subsets = 581"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 10 chairs in a row. How many ways can you choose a consecutive subset of at least 3 chairs? The final answer is 581.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum> n \<in> {3..chairs}. (binomial (chairs - n + 1) n))"
and h2 : "\<forall> S. S \<subseteq> {1..chairs} \<and> card S \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> b = (a + 1) mod chairs \<and> c = (b + 1) mod chairs)"
shows  "subsets = 581"

theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum> n \<in> {3..chairs}. (binomial (chairs - n + 1) n))"
and h2 : "\<forall> S. S \<subseteq> {1..chairs} \<and> card S \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> b = (a + 1) mod chairs \<and> c = (b + 1) mod chairs)"
shows  "subsets = 581"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 10 chairs arranged in a circle. Find the number of ways to choose a subset of 3 or more chairs such that there are at least 3 consecutive chairs in the subset. The final answer is 581.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: "nat set set"
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = {S. S \<subseteq> {1..chairs} \<and> (\<exists>a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> ((a + 1) mod chairs = b \<or> (a + 2) mod chairs = b) \<and> ((b + 1) mod chairs = c \<or> (b + 2) mod chairs = c))}"
shows  "card subsets = 581"

theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: "nat set set"
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = {S. S \<subseteq> {1..chairs} \<and> (\<exists>a b c. a \<in> S \<and> b \<in> S \<and> c \<in> S \<and> ((a + 1) mod chairs = b \<or> (a + 2) mod chairs = b) \<and> ((b + 1) mod chairs = c \<or> (b + 2) mod chairs = c))}"
shows  "card subsets = 581"

a_2.informal problem: There are 10 chairs arranged in a circle. How many ways can you choose a subset of 3 chairs such that the first and second chairs are either adjacent or have one chair between them, and the second and third chairs also have the same condition? The final answer is 581.

and h1 : "at_least_three_adjacent_chairs (chairs) = 581"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (card {S. S \<subseteq> {1..chairs} \<and> (\<exists>i. i \<in> {1..chairs} \<and> (i mod chairs) + 1 \<in> S \<and> (i+1) mod chairs + 1 \<in> S \<and> (i+2) mod chairs + 1 \<in> S)})"
shows  "subsets = 581"

fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat

a_4.informal problem: There are 10 chairs arranged in a circle. How many subsets of these chairs can you form such that there are at least three consecutive chairs in each subset? The final answer is 581.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>subset. subset \<subseteq> {1..chairs} \<longrightarrow> card subset \<ge> 3 \<and> (\<exists>x \<in> subset. (\<exists>y \<in> subset. (\<exists>z \<in> subset. x \<noteq> y \<and> x \<noteq> z \<and> y \<noteq> z \<and> ((x+1) mod chairs = y \<or> (x+1) mod chairs = z) \<and> ((y+1) mod chairs = x \<or> (y+1) mod chairs = z) \<and> ((z+1) mod chairs = x \<or> (z+1) mod chairs = y))))) \<Longrightarrow> subsets = 581"
shows  "subsets = 581"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ten chairs are arranged in a circle. Find the number of subsets of this set of chairs that contain at least three adjacent chairs.
 The final Answer is 581
 ### Proof

There are $10$ subsets of $4$ chairs where all $4$ are adjacent, and $10 \cdot 5$ or $50$ where there are only $3.$ If there are $5$ chairs, $10$ have all $5$ adjacent, $10 \cdot 4$ or $40$ have $4$ adjacent, and $10 \cdot {5\choose 2}$ or $100$ have $3$ adjacent.

 All possible subsets with more than $6$ chairs have at least $1$ group of $3$ adjacent chairs, so we add ${10\choose7}$ or $120$, ${10\choose8}$ or $45$, ${10\choose9}$ or $10$, and ${10\choose10}$ or $1.$ Adding, we get $10 + 10 + 50 + 10 + 40 + 100 + 10 + 30 + 60 + 15 + 70 + 120 + 45 + 10 + 1 = \boxed{581}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>subset. subset \<subseteq> {1..chairs} \<longrightarrow> card subset \<ge> 3 \<and> (\<exists>x \<in> subset. (\<exists>y \<in> subset. (\<exists>z \<in> subset. x \<noteq> y \<and> x \<noteq> z \<and> y \<noteq> z \<and> ((x+1) mod chairs = y \<or> (x+1) mod chairs = z) \<and> ((y+1) mod chairs = x \<or> (y+1) mod chairs = z) \<and> ((z+1) mod chairs = x \<or> (z+1) mod chairs = y))))) \<Longrightarrow> subsets = 581"
shows  "subsets = 581"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a circular arrangement of 10 chairs, how many subsets of chairs can be formed such that there are at least 3 chairs in each subset and any 3 chairs in the subset have at least 2 chairs adjacent to each other? The final answer is 581.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = card {S. S \<subseteq> {1..10} \<and> (\<exists>i. i \<in> {1..10} \<and> (i mod 10) + 1 \<in> S \<and> (i mod 10) + 2 \<in> S \<and> (i mod 10) + 3 \<in> S)}"
shows  "subsets = 581"
a_6.formal solution:

theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = card {S. S \<subseteq> {1..10} \<and> (\<exists>i. i \<in> {1..10} \<and> (i mod 10) + 1 \<in> S \<and> (i mod 10) + 2 \<in> S \<and> (i mod 10) + 3 \<in> S)}"
shows  "subsets = 581"

a_6.informal problem: There are 10 chairs numbered from 1 to 10. How many subsets of chairs can be formed such that there exists a chair number i in the subset, and the chairs with numbers (i mod 10) + 1, (i mod 10) + 2, and (i mod 10) + 3 are also in the subset? The final answer is 581.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum>i \<in> {3..10}. 2^(chairs - i))"
shows  "subsets = 581"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes chairs subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum>i \<in> {3..10}. 2^(chairs - i))"
shows  "subsets = 581"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: There are 10 chairs in a row. Find the total number of ways to select a subset of chairs such that at least 3 chairs are left unselected. The final answer is 581.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum>k | k \<ge> 3 \<and> k \<le> 10. (10 choose k) * (k choose 3))"
shows  "subsets = 581"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ten chairs are arranged in a circle. Find the number of subsets of this set of chairs that contain at least three adjacent chairs.
 The final Answer is 581
 ### Proof
 We know that a subset with less than $3$ chairs cannot contain $3$ adjacent chairs. There are only $10$ sets of $3$ chairs so that they are all $3$ adjacent.  All possible subsets with more than $6$ chairs have at least $1$ group of $3$ adjacent chairs, so we add ${10\choose7}$ or $120$, ${10\choose8}$ or $45$, ${10\choose9}$ or $10$, and ${10\choose10}$ or $1.$ Adding, we get $10 + 10 + 50 + 10 + 40 + 100 + 10 + 30 + 60 + 15 + 70 + 120 + 45 + 10 + 1 = \boxed{581}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes chairs :: nat and subsets :: nat
assumes h0 : "chairs = 10"
and h1 : "subsets = (\<Sum>k | k \<ge> 3 \<and> k \<le> 10. (10 choose k) * (k choose 3))"
shows  "subsets = 581"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a room, there are 10 chairs. How many ways can you choose at least 3 chairs and arrange them in groups of 3? The final answer is 581.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and chairs :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card chairs = 10"
and h1 : "at_least_three_adjacent_subsets chairs = n"
shows  "n = 581"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ten chairs are arranged in a circle. Find the number of subsets of this set of chairs that contain at least three adjacent chairs.
 The final Answer is 581
 ### Proof
 We know that a subset with less than $3$ chairs cannot contain $3$ adjacent chairs. There are only $10$ sets of $3$ chairs so that they are all $3$ adjacent.  All possible subsets with more than $6$ chairs have at least $1$ group of $3$ adjacent chairs, so we add ${10\choose7}$ or $120$, ${10\choose8}$ or $45$, ${10\choose9}$ or $10$, and ${10\choose10}$ or $1.$ Adding, we get $10 + 10 + 50 + 10 + 40 + 100 + 10 + 30 + 60 + 15 + 70 + 120 + 45 + 10 + 1 = \boxed{581}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and chairs :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card chairs = 10"
and h1 : "at_least_three_adjacent_subsets chairs = n"
shows  "n = 581"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 10 chairs in a row. Find the number of ways to choose a subset of chairs such that there are at least three adjacent chairs in the chosen subset. The final answer is 581.
